text: Hello everyone.
Welcome to our course on blockchains and cryptocurrencies.
My name is Dan Boneh.
I'm a co-director of the Stanford Center for Blockchain Research
and a Professor of Computer Science here at Stanford.
I'm co-teaching this course along with my colleague, Professor Joe Grundfest.
Thank you, Dan. Hello everyone.
My name is Joe Grundfest.
I'm a former commissioner of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission,
but I'm better now, thanks for asking.
I'm also a Professor of Law and Business here at Stanford.
This course is a special collaboration between
the Computer Science Department at Stanford and Stanford Law School.
Our goal is to look at blockchain technology through
a variety of lenses including those of developers,
investors, regulators, and the media.
Along with your instructors,
you'll hear from rising stars in this space including Juan Benet,
founder of Filecoin and CEO of Protocol Labs,
as well as Fred Ehrsam and Matt Huang of Paradigm,
Fred is co-founder of Coinbase and Matt is a former partner at Sequoia Capital.
Together, they offer absolutely tremendous insight
that you simply can't get anywhere else.
By the end of this course,
you should understand how blockchain technologies and cryptocurrencies work,
what the immediate and long-term opportunities are,
as well as their challenges.
We want to arm you with enough information to decide for
yourself how the technology will evolve and what its impact will be.
We hope you enjoy the course and we very much
look forward to speaking to you soon. Thank you very much.
Thanks everyone, and we hope you enjoy the course.
